page.title: Topic 3 Overview
page.contents:
Summative Assessment – The Standardized Test

In the last lesson, you became familiar with diagnostic, formative and summative assessment, and what each is used for.  You also explored who the stakeholders are in your program, and which assessments best serve each stakeholder’s needs.  In this lesson, we will focus on one summative assessment that in adult education is typically used for gauging advancement in education and reporting to funders:  the standardized test.  Standardized tests can also be the source of anxiety for many adult basic education students.  Two readings will provide insight into the nature of standardized tests and what teachers can do to help their students prepare to take them successfully. 

The Lesson Objectives for Topic 3 are to:  

  • be able to describe and provide examples of summative assessment;
  • learn commonly used assessment-related terms;
  • read about using test scores to identify strengths and needs;
  • learn about maximizing your students’ ability to perform well on tests;
  • report on progress you have made toward your chosen goal.

page.title: Types of Summative Assessment
page.contents:
Understanding Standardized Tests

The article below provides an overview of one of the most common types of summative assessments:  the standardized test.  Standardized tests are broadly used in education at all ages and levels, and they are used to gauge success in teaching and learning, decide qualifications for advancement in education or employment, and determine levels of funding. This primer from Adventures in Assessment is a guide for the program administrator and/or classroom teacher on how to effectively use standardized tests to identify student strengths and needs.  

A Basic Primer for Understanding Standardized Tests and Using Test Scores (pdf format)
By April Zenisky, Lisa Keller, Stephen G. Sireci; in Adventures in Assessment, Vol. 16, Spring 2004. UMass Amherst

Questions for Discussion:

As you read, we ask you to consider how you use and might use standardized test scores to identify your students’ strengths and needs. 

  • If you already do use standardized test scores to identify strengths and needs, how would you describe what you do?  How useful is it? How might you change/improve this process?  
  • If you don’t currently use standardized test scores in this way, what are some examples of how you might modify your instruction or program processes to do so? How do you think this change might improve student learning?
